oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Richardson and Cox, engravers
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Execution of Jacob Harmon and his son Henry
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: George W. Childs, Applegate & Co., Philadelphia
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image depicts a man and a youth standing on a wooden platform as nooses are placed around their necks by two other men while a uniformed soldier stands alongside with sword raised in the air. In the foreground are several uniformed soldiers next to a wagon. There are several agitated bystanders, a man on horseback, and a Confederate flag in the right section of the image.

Jacob Harmon and his son Henry belonged to a group of Union loyalists who destroyed the Lick Creek Bridge on the East Tennessee & Virginia Railroad on the night of November 8-9, 1861. One of their number, Christopher Haun, a master potter, was hanged by Confederate officials in Knoxville on 10 December 1861. These men, along with Henry Fry and Jacob Hensie or Hinshaw, were among the five executed for their actions disrupting the movement of Confederate troops and supplies into upper East Tennessee. This image appeared on page 319 of William G. Brownlow's Sketches of the Rise, Progress, and Decline of Secession; with a Narrative of Personal Adventures Among the Rebels (Philadelphia: George W. Childs, Applegate & Co., 1862)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: nited States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Destruction and Pillage--Union
Walking a Fine Line
